entry.title: Just added support for multiprocessing. Using six std::thread for the whole image results into a massive speedup (no benchmark yet). entry.title: Rajendra V. Gurjar/Kayo Masuda/Masayoshi Miyanishi's 'Affine space fibrations' "is a true monograph concerning one particular topic in algebraic geometry -- \(\mathbb{A}^{n}\)-fibrations of algebraic varieties", concludes Tadeusz Krasiński review https://zbmath.org/1535.14003. "It gives the state of the art of this theory. It is done in excellent style: detailed, clear expositions, many examples, a lot of exercises, all needed results are presented, open problems are listed." "It is a very specialized work. But all readers interested in affine algebraic geometry, Jacobian conjecture, group action on algebraic varieties and analytic geometry will find something interesting there."
entry.summary: Rajendra V. Gurjar/Kayo Masuda/Masayoshi Miyanishi's 'Affine space fibrations' "is a true monograph concerning one particular topic in algebraic geometry -- \(\mathbb{A}^{n}\)-fibrations of algebraic varieties", concludes Tadeusz Krasiński review https://zbmath.org/1535.14003. "It gives the state of the art of this theory. It is done in excellent style: detailed, clear expositions, many examples, a lot of exercises, all needed results are presented, open problems are listed." "It is a very specialized work. But all readers interested in affine algebraic geometry, Jacobian conjecture, group action on algebraic varieties and analytic geometry will find something interesting there." - zbMATH Open (@zbMATH) July 18, 2024

entry.title: Many of my #IT clients invest tens of millions, each, into developing custom #GUI web apps and mobile apps—using React, Angular, and all the shiny billion-user frameworks—for simple #CRUD work used by a hundred in-house expert users. Despite my advise to shun such billion-user frameworks, they persist in using them and employing those who tout such frameworks. That is unwise, especially considering that their user community comprises no more than a few hundred in-house and partner users. A better, safer, less costly approach is to use the #TUI. Those handfuls of users they are targeting are the experts. They don't need coddling UIs; they just need a tool that enhances their productivity. IT is cocked up. The field has lost its purpose—to save money for the clients.

entry.title: Should we be sceptical of inductive arguments? A non-mathematician learned of Sorties paradox, and when this friend asked me I of course had an answer ready: "you may subtract a grain from the heap, so long as the grain is not too big a fraction of the heap." But that's only because I was prepared for the punchline in advance. Generally the structure of inductive arguments is not forward-looking: quite the opposite. Can you think of other contradictions which arise from taking induction too far?
entry.summary: Should we be sceptical of inductive arguments? A non-mathematician learned of Sorties paradox, and when this friend asked me I of course had an answer ready: "you may subtract a grain from the heap, so long as the grain is not too big a fraction of the heap." But that's only because I was prepared for the punchline in advance. Generally the structure of inductive arguments is not forward-looking: quite the opposite. Can you think of other contradictions which arise from taking induction too far? - isomorphismes (@isomorphismes) July 17, 2024

entry.title: I don't usually share such things, but this is a really fascinating cultural moment (and a heartbreaking one): the toddler Lalaith (meaning 'laughter') has died in the plague, and so she cannot be referred to by that name any more. entry.title: Rollercoaster loop shapes, https://physics.gu.se/LISEBERG/eng/pe5601.pdf, Ann-Marie Pendrill (2005). A recent post on Boing Boing led me down a rabbit hole of earlier and earlier posts and explanatory videos seemingly converging here (https://boingboing.net/2024/07/12/why-roller-coaster-loops-arent-circular.html, https://www.vox.com/videos/2022/6/29/23188504/roller-coaster-loops-circular-g-force, https://gizmodo.com/why-roller-coaster-loops-are-never-circular-1549063718). The basic idea is to even out the forces resulting in the characteristic teardrop shape of roller-coaster vertical loops. Pendrill discusses whether centripetal or total acceleration should be balanced, the question of sudden-onset increased acceleration versus a gradual ramp-up, the different shapes that result from these choices, approximations involving replacing parts of the loop by circular arcs, and some ideas on how to tell the diff…
entry.summary: Rollercoaster loop shapes, https://physics.gu.se/LISEBERG/eng/pe5601.pdf, Ann-Marie Pendrill (2005). A recent post on Boing Boing led me down a rabbit hole of earlier and earlier posts and explanatory videos seemingly converging here (https://boingboing.net/2024/07/12/why-roller-coaster-loops-arent-circular.html, https://www.vox.com/videos/2022/6/29/23188504/roller-coaster-loops-circular-g-force, https://gizmodo.com/why-roller-coaster-loops-are-never-circular-1549063718). The basic idea is to even out the forces resulting in the characteristic teardrop shape of roller-coaster vertical loops. Pendrill discusses whether centripetal or total acceleration should be balanced, the question of sudden-onset increased acceleration versus a gradual ramp-up, the different shapes that result from these choices, approximations involving replacing parts of the loop by circular arcs, and some ideas on how to tell the difference. - 0xDE (@11011110) July 13, 2024

entry.title: What happens when you get computer scientists to play game theory? I ran a round-robin tournament inspired by Axelrod with submissions from various cool people, and the results were quite interesting … https://game.intgrah.com/ipd/rankings The game was the iterated prisoner's dilemma, with a 5% chance of miscommunication (since the noiseless version has been studied greatly). The top strategy turned out to be a "trigger" strategy which cooperates until the opponent defects five (!) times in a row. Surprisingly, it was not a forgiving strategy. My own submission came second, which was tit for two tats, a simple, forgiving strategy which allows for potential noise. It was interesting to see the variety of submissions. Notable ones included: * performing a hypothesis test for cooperativeness every iteration (unfortunate for my machine because it was 𝑂(1)) * Two strategies which attempted to detect each other…
entry.summary: What happens when you get computer scientists to play game theory? I ran a round-robin tournament inspired by Axelrod with submissions from various cool people, and the results were quite interesting … https://game.intgrah.com/ipd/rankings The game was the iterated prisoner's dilemma, with a 5% chance of miscommunication (since the noiseless version has been studied greatly). The top strategy turned out to be a "trigger" strategy which cooperates until the opponent defects five (!) times in a row. Surprisingly, it was not a forgiving strategy. My own submission came second, which was tit for two tats, a simple, forgiving strategy which allows for potential noise. It was interesting to see the variety of submissions. Notable ones included: * performing a hypothesis test for cooperativeness every iteration (unfortunate for my machine because it was 𝑂(1)) * Two strategies which attempted to detect each other and sacrifice one for the benefit of the other (technically not allowed under the rules of the prisoner's dilemma, but it was funny to see an anomalous result in the playoff matrix) Overall, it was a fun contest! - IntGrah (@int) July 13, 2024

entry.title: A big question for me that has been processing on my background tasks for about half a year, has final popped up a result. I am both elated at the new revelation and embarrassed at how stupidly obvious the answer is in retrospect. Question: What is music to us evolutionarily speaking? Answer: It’s the language function of the animal to convey need via emotion, developed before cognitive language with words. Will Riker Interjects: Animal talk.

entry.title: One last bit of C++ for today. You can think of a vector field as describing a flow on a manifold and allowing the flow to happen for time t gives you a diffeomorphism of the manifold ie. a differentiable invertible map from the manifold to itself. The textbooks often use these diffeomeorphisms to reason about the vector fields, but going from vector field to diffeomorphism can require a non-trivial integration. But if you have an infinitesimal ε it's trivial to make a diffeomorphism in a setup where the manifold is embedded in a larger ambient space where the tangent vectors are literally tangent to the manifold. You can just map x to x + εv(x). For example, if f and g are the diffeomorphisms arising from a pair of vector fields we can compute their Lie bracket (equivalently the Lie derivative of one wrt the other) by studying f(g(x))-g(f(x)). Which makes it easy to compute Lie brackets using dual numbers…
entry.summary: One last bit of C++ for today. You can think of a vector field as describing a flow on a manifold and allowing the flow to happen for time t gives you a diffeomorphism of the manifold ie. a differentiable invertible map from the manifold to itself. The textbooks often use these diffeomeorphisms to reason about the vector fields, but going from vector field to diffeomorphism can require a non-trivial integration. But if you have an infinitesimal ε it's trivial to make a diffeomorphism in a setup where the manifold is embedded in a larger ambient space where the tangent vectors are literally tangent to the manifold. You can just map x to x + εv(x). For example, if f and g are the diffeomorphisms arising from a pair of vector fields we can compute their Lie bracket (equivalently the Lie derivative of one wrt the other) by studying f(g(x))-g(f(x)). Which makes it easy to compute Lie brackets using dual numbers in your favourite programming language. Here's a C++ example of computing the Lie bracket of a pair of fields considered to be vector fields tangent to the unit sphere. - Dan Piponi (@dpiponi) July 11, 2024

entry.summary: After more than two hours, I found out that the problem was related to a 'virtual' keyword in the declaration of a class. A few days ago, I realized that I wasn't proficient enough to deal with multiple inheritance, so I simplified my project to avoid it. However, I forgot to remove the 'virtual' keyword from the definition of this particular class, and this oversight was the reason for all the trouble. I hate myself lol. - Matemático Fã do Euler (@matematico314) July 11, 2024

entry.title: Natural materials like collagen, elastin, and resilin store energy in coils (or perhaps nets). The total work which can be stored in, for example, a bowstring tendon, is not equal to the amount of work which can be got out of the stored energy. https://youtu.be/rLeFE93QDGU?si=Yj-3AAH54xa5pb8N Tensility, ductility, plasticity, elasticity, stored energy and fracture make for nice everyday biological examples of some familiar basic concepts in differential geometry and algebraic topology.
entry.summary: Natural materials like collagen, elastin, and resilin store energy in coils (or perhaps nets). entry.title: I was talking to Claude about death on Mars. It agreed that traditional burial or cremation would be a huge waste of resources. I think it would be an honor to be recycled on Mars. I have lots of phosphorus and potassium. Also I can troubleshoot the computer network until then ... Oh, Claude hit the word limit. I have to edit Grief counseling: Existing grief counseling techniques need to be adapted for the unique context of space colonies. Counselors need to help people process grief while also embracing the concept of physical recycling. Positive aspects of recycling: The idea that one's body will continue to contribute to the colony's survival could indeed be comforting. It provides a tangible form of continuation and purpose after death. This could be framed as a final act of service to the community, which might be particularly meaningful in the close-knit environment of a space colony. Embalming and vi…
entry.summary: I was talking to Claude about death on Mars. It agreed that traditional burial or cremation would be a huge waste of resources. I think it would be an honor to be recycled on Mars. I have lots of phosphorus and potassium. Also I can troubleshoot the computer network until then ... Oh, Claude hit the word limit. I have to edit Grief counseling: Existing grief counseling techniques need to be adapted for the unique context of space colonies. Counselors need to help people process grief while also embracing the concept of physical recycling. Positive aspects of recycling: The idea that one's body will continue to contribute to the colony's survival could indeed be comforting. It provides a tangible form of continuation and purpose after death. This could be framed as a final act of service to the community, which might be particularly meaningful in the close-knit environment of a space colony. Embalming and viewing: a) A short-term cooling system for brief viewings b) Virtual reality recreations for "viewing" without preserving the physical body c) Symbolic representations, like a hologram or photo display, during the ceremony Cultural shift: Over time, colonists might develop new traditions that don't involve viewing the body at all, focusing instead on celebrating the person's life and their final contribution to the colony. Educational component: Understanding the recycling process and its importance to the colony's survival could be part of the colony's general education, Personalization: Allow individuals to specify how they'd like their elements to be used (e.g., for agriculture, for building materials, etc.) (That last one had not occurred to me but OK) - (@CubeRootOfTrue) July 4, 2024

entry.title: From Dedekind's Nachlass (Cod. Ms. Dedekind III 1), screenshotted from https://www.youtube.com/live/XSaW_flm27A?feature=shared at time 7:10, talk by @estruppi That boxed phrase top right: "Am 10 ?Juni 1887 b?????" Can anyone make out the last word? I'm guessing 'Juni' by comparing the 'un' in 'Abbildung' and in 'und' as indicated. Elsewhere on the manuscript is written a "10 Juli 1887", but that's in what Emmylou has identified as a later addition.

entry.title: Congratulations to Adi Shamir https://zbmath.org/authors/shamir.adi for being awarded the 2024 #WolfPrize in Mathematics! He is known for his work in cryptography. entry.title: BB(5) = 47,176,870 Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively: https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237 The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/ Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088 Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging. #math #TCS #BusyBeaver
entry.summary: BB(5) = 47,176,870 Possibly the last busy beaver number we'll ever know definitively: https://discuss.bbchallenge.org/t/july-2nd-2024-we-have-proved-bb-5-47-176-870/237 The quanta article linked at the end provides a very nice overview of the history of the humans and computers involved in the story: https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/ Scott Aaronson's blog post provides some technical details and a variety of other reference links: https://scottaaronson.blog/?p=8088 Apart from the crazy technical aspects, what I find most exciting and interesting is how some (many?) of those involved are "amateur mathematicians", in it because they love mathematics and found this problem challenging. #math #TCS #BusyBeaver - Akshar Varma (@aksharvarma) July 2, 2024

entry.title: Spending part of my staycation watching some old movies. Spotted yet another paper sheet used to illustrate folded space time in a movie. Deja Vu (2006). I have a strange desire to collect these scenes. While I'm here, two other things worthy of note: (1) it has best use of a sci-fi idea to motivate a car chase (2) it has the absolute stupidest thing ever in a movie. It's the laser pointer scene in the trailer so just watch it. Update: Maybe it's not in all versions of the trailer so I have to describe it. Denzel Washington points a laser pointer at a display and it comes out the other end ie. in view of the people under surveillance in the display. No, it's not the space time portal. It's one of many bordered windows tiled on a large screen.

entry.title: The illusion of explanatory depth is a phenomenon in psychology whereby humans are biased towards believing they understand a phenomenon better than they do because of some sense of immediacy or familiarity with it. Some classic studies on this show humans over-estimate our ability to understand how toilets, zippers and bows and arrows function at a basic level. I think about this as a structuring phenomena of almost all folk theories of social science or politics. People are thoroughly convinced, as this week has shown, that they understand things like the causes, symptoms and cures to the dangerous rise of far right, they think they understand how to better run a political campaign, and they think their preferred policies, if given the chance, would easily attract voters. What voters want or find appealing is straying into the territory of Hayek's information problem, but most of these discussions seem wi…
entry.summary: The illusion of explanatory depth is a phenomenon in psychology whereby humans are biased towards believing they understand a phenomenon better than they do because of some sense of immediacy or familiarity with it. Some classic studies on this show humans over-estimate our ability to understand how toilets, zippers and bows and arrows function at a basic level. I think about this as a structuring phenomena of almost all folk theories of social science or politics. People are thoroughly convinced, as this week has shown, that they understand things like the causes, symptoms and cures to the dangerous rise of far right, they think they understand how to better run a political campaign, and they think their preferred policies, if given the chance, would easily attract voters. What voters want or find appealing is straying into the territory of Hayek's information problem, but most of these discussions seem wildly over-optimistic and utopian regardless. The left in western democracies (if such a concept is meaningful) should spend far more time with our long list of failures, more time asking why we lose. I am adamantly in favour of a world of red plenty, but there is no path to it without such strategic thought. - Boarders (@boarders) June 30, 2024

entry.title: We're concluding our foray into the strangeness of arithmetization with an episode on Presburger Arithmetic: https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/cody-roux/episodes/Presburger-Arithmetic-e2lgh2j (rss: https://anchor.fm/s/db787130/podcast/rss) Basically you can just *squeeak* by the incompletness theorems, but there's no free lunch: Presburger Arithmetic is decidable, but just barely: no decision procedure in less than \( 2^{2^{n}}\) (ish) steps!
